Pysics Reference¶

module pysics.manager¶

class pysics.manager.PhysicsManager(objects=[], tick_length=1.0, time_passed=0.0)¶

Represents a universe in which physics works the way it does in that universe. Time (ticks) passes individually in each universe.

Parameters

  • tick_length (float) – The amount of time, in seconds, a tick is for this universe. This can be changed after initialization. Time can move backwards.

  • time_passed (float) – The amount of time, in seconds, that has passed in this manager’s universe.

objects¶

All the objects within this universe. Ticks pass for all objects when tick() is called.

Type

List[pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject]

tick_length¶

The configured value of how many seconds a tick is. Recommended to be small for games to reduce/prevent collision issues. Yes, time can move backwards.

Type

float

time_passed¶

The amount of time, in seconds, that has passed in this universe. Not necessarily the same for all objects within this universe (in case objects are within multiple universes, or an object is ticked individually)

Type

float

tick(tick_length=None)¶

Make a single physics tick pass for all objects in this universe.

If tick_length is not supplied, then use the universe’s tick length.

Parameters

tick_length (float) –

The amount of time this tick lasts.

Note

Time can move backwards.

tick_object(obj: pysics.obj.PhysicsObject)¶

Make a single physics tick pass for a single object. The tick_length is this manager’s configured length.

This can be achieved by calling pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject.tick() and providing the configured tick_length.

Parameters

obj (pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject) – The object that is to be ticked.

add_object(ph_obj: pysics.obj.PhysicsObject)¶

Add an object to this universe. Adds the object to the end of the objects list.

Parameters

ph_obj (pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject) – The object to be added to this universe.

Raises

pysics.errors.NameUsedError – There cannot be two objects in one universe with the same name.

remove_object(obj: pysics.obj.PhysicsObject)¶

Remove a physics object using the instance itself.

Parameters

obj (pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject) – The object to remove from this universe (the instance itself).

remove_object_by_name()¶

Remove a physics object using its name.

If there is no object with the given name, fails silently.

Parameters

name (str) – The name of the object to be removed.

clear() → tuple¶

Remove all physics objects from the universe. Clears the objects list.

Returns

All the objects that were previously a part of this universe. Useful for transferring all objects to a different universe.

Return type

List[pysics.physics_obj.PhysicsObject]

module pysics.obj¶

class pysics.obj.PhysicsObject(name, xpos=0.0, ypos=0.0, zpos=0.0, xvel=0.0, yvel=0.0, zvel=0.0, x_orientation=0.0, y_orientation=0.0, z_orientation=0.0, x_angular_vel=0.0, y_angular_vel=0.0, z_angular_vel=0.0, forces=[], mass=1.0, moment_of_inertia=1.0, time_passed=0.0)¶

Represents an object in space that will react as forces are applied on it over ticks (time). Acceleration is only calculated when the object moves (at the beginning of each tick). Acceleration can be manually calculated with PhysicsObject.calculate_accel(). Objects have a mass of 1 kilogram by default.

Parameters

  • name (str) – The name of this object.

  • xpos (float) – The object’s initial position on the x axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. East is positive, West is negative.

  • ypos (float) – The object’s initial position on the y axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. Up is positive, Down is negative.

  • zpos (float) – The object’s initial position on the z axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. North is positive, South is negative.

  • xvel (float) – The object’s velocity on the x axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. East is positive, West is negative.

  • yvel (float) – The object’s velocity on the y axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. Up is positive, Down is negative.

  • zvel (float) – The object’s velocity on the z axis. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided. North is positive, South is negative.

  • x_orientation (float) – The object’s initial orientation on the x axis in radians. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • y_orientation (float) – The object’s initial orientation on the y axis in radians. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • z_orientation (float) – The object’s initial orientation on the z axis in radians. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • x_angular_vel (float) – The object’s initial angular velocity on the x axis in radians per second. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • y_angular_vel (float) – The object’s initial angular velocity on the y axis in radians per second. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • z_angular_vel (float) – The object’s initial angular velocity on the z axis in radians per second. Defaults to 0.0 if not provided.

  • forces (list[pysics.force.Force]) – The forces that will act on this object. Defaults to no forces. Useful for creating many PhysicsObjects.

  • mass (float) – The mass of this object. Defaults to 1 kilogram (in case you don’t want to deal with mass)

  • moment_of_inertia (float) – The moment of inertia of this object (how easily the object rotates). Defaults to 1 kg*m.

  • time_passed (float) – The total amount of time, in seconds, that has passed for this object.

name¶

The name of this physics object. It cannot be the same as another object’s name in the same universe.

Type

str

forces¶

All the forces that act on this object each tick.

Type

list[pysics.force.Force]

mass¶

This object’s mass.

Type

float

moment_of_inertia¶

This object’s moment of inertia (how easily it can rotate)

Type

float

xpos¶

This object’s position on the x axis in meters. East is positive, West is negative.

Type

float

ypos¶

This object’s position on the y axis in meters. Up is positive, Down is negative.

Type

float

zpos¶

This object’s position on the z axis in meters. North is positive, South is negative.

Type

float

xvel¶

This object’s translational velocity on the x axis in meters per second. East is positive, West is negative.

Type

float

yvel¶

This object’s translational velocity on the y xis in meters per second. Up is positive, Down is negatives.

Type

float

zvel¶

This object’s translational velocity on the z axis in meters per second. North is positive, South is negative.

Type

float

xaccel¶

This object’s translational acceleration on the x axis in meters per second^2. East is positive, West is negaitve.

Type

float

yaccel¶

This object’s translational acceleration on the y axis in meters per second^2. Up is positive, Down is negaitve.

Type

float

zaccel¶

This object’s translational acceleration on the z axis in meters per second^2. North is positive, South is negaitve.

Type

float

x_orientation¶

The object’s orientation on the x axis in radians.

Type

float

y_orientation¶

The object’s orientation on the y axis in radians.

Type

float

z_orientation¶

The object’s orientation on the z axis in radians.

Type

float

x_angular_vel¶

The object’s angular velocity on the x axis in radians per second.

Type

float

y_angular_vel¶

The object’s angular velocity on the y axis in radians per second.

Type

float

z_angular_vel¶

The object’s angular velocity on the z axis in radians per second.

Type

float

x_angular_accel¶

The object’s angular acceleration on the x axis in radians per second^2.

Type

float

y_angular_accel¶

The object’s angular acceleration on the y axis in radians per second^2.

Type

float

z_angular_accel¶

The object’s angular acceleration on the z axis in radians per second^2.

Type

float

time_passed¶

The amount of time, in seconds, that has passed for this object (total time over all ticks).

Type

float

Raises

MassOfZeroError – Raised if an object is given a mass of 0 on initialization.

tick(tick_length: float)¶

Time passes for this object.

Forces will be applied and the object will move based on velocity and acceleration.

Acceleration is recalculated just before the position and velocity are updated.

Translational position/velocity is calculated first.

Parameters

tick_length (float) – The amount of time that passes this tick.

get_pos() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current position on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s position on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

get_orientation() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current orientation on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s position on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

get_vel() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current velocity on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s velocity on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

get_angular_vel() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current angular velocity on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s velocity on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

get_accel() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current translational acceleration on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s translational acceleration on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

get_angular_accel() → tuple¶

Returns the object’s current angular acceleration on each axis in the form (x, y, z)

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s acceleration on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float)

calculate_accel() → tuple¶

Calculates and sets the object’s translational (linear) acceleration for each dimension.

Adds all the newtons of force for each dimension from forces, then divides each result by the mass.

This is called when a tick() is called. Translational acceleration can be updated manually by calling this function.

Returns

Returns a tuple of the object’s acceleration on the 3 dimensions (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple(float, float, float, float, float)

Raises

MassOfZeroError – PhysicsObjects cannot have a mass of 0. Prevents from dividing by 0.

calculate_angular_accel() → tuple¶

Calculates and sets the object’s angular acceleration for each dimension.

Adds all the newtons of force for each dimension from forces, then divides each result by the moment_of_inertia.

This is called when a tick() is called. Angular acceleration can be updated manually by calling this function.

Returns

The angular acceleration of the 3 dimensions in the form: (x, y, z)

Return type

tuple( float, float, float)

Raises

MomentOfInertiaZeroError – PhysicsObjects cannot have a moment of inertia of 0. Prevents from dividing by 0.

apply_force(new_force)¶

Applies another force on this object.

Parameters

new_force (new_force) – The force instance that will be applied to this object.

Raises

pysics.errors.NameUsedError – You cannot use the same name twice for a force on the same object.

remove_force(force)¶

Remove a force from this object so that it is no longer applied (removes from forces). Fails silently if there is no force with the given name.

Parameters

force (pysics.force.Force) – The instance of the force to remove.

remove_force_by_name(name: str)¶

Remove a force based on its name so that it is no longer applied to this object (removes from forces). Fails silently if there is no force with the given name.

Parameters

name (str) – The name of the force to be removed.

clear_forces() → list¶

Remove all the forces acting on this object (Empties forces).

Returns

All the forces cleared. Useful for transferring forces to another object.

Return type

list[pysics.force.Force]

module pysics.force¶

pysics.force.EARTH_G = 9.80665¶

The gravitational acceleration on the surface of the Earth in m/s^2

pysics.force.MOON_G = 1.625¶

The gravitational acceleration on the surface of the Moon in m/s^2

pysics.force.MARS_G = 3.72076¶

The gravitational acceleration on the surface of Mars in m/s^2

pysics.force.calculate_grav_force(g=9.80665, parent_mass=1) → float¶

Calculate the gravitational force that would be applied to an object with the given mass given a gravitational acceleration.

Calculation: gravitational force = mg

  • m is the mass of the parent object.

  • g is the gravitational acceleration (the gravitational constant).

Parameters

  • g (float) – The gravitational acceleration (gravitational constant). This is the resulting acceleration from the force. Defaults to EARTH_G (9.80665 m/s^2)

  • parent_mass (float) – The mass of the object the gravitational force will be applied to. Defaults to 1 kilogram.

Returns

The newtons of force that would be required to have a mass of parent_mass accelerate at g m/s^2. The force you will make from this does not necessarily have to be on the y (vertical) axis. Why not have gravity be sideways?

Return type

float

class pysics.force.Force(name, x=0.0, y=0.0, z=0.0, force_type=0, x_rotation_axis_distance=0.0, y_rotation_axis_distance=0.0, z_rotation_axis_distance=0.0, x_rot_angle=0.0, y_rot_angle=0.0, z_rot_angle=0.0)¶

A force that acts upon a PhysicsObject.

The x, y, and z attributes can be used freely by developers (meaning you can use any axis as you wish. For example, you could use the universe’s y axis as your z axis). If you desire to only have 2D motion, then completely ignore an entire dimension. If you wish to only have 1D motion, the ignore 2 dimensions.

It is not recommended that the variable that stores a Force be called force, because that is also the name of the module force, which could cause naming conflicts.

Parameters

  • name (str) – The force’s name. Used to identify this force when applied to an object.

  • x (float) – The newtons of force in the x direction. Defaults to 0.0 if not supplied. East is positive, West is negative.

  • y (float) – The newtons of force in the x direction. Defaults to 0.0 if not supplied. Up is positive, Down is negative.

  • z (float) – The newtons of force in the x direction. Defaults to 0.0 if not supplied. North is positive, South is negative.

  • force_type (int) –

    Represents the type of force this is with the following values:

    • 0: Applied Force

    • 1: Gravitational Force

    • 2: Frictional Force (Not yet implemented)

    • 3: Tension (Not yet implemented)

    • 4: Air Resistance (Not yet implemented)

    Note

    force_type is currently unused and will not change (will always stay initial value)

  • x_rotation_axis_distance (float) – The distance from the axis of rotation on the x-axis in meters. Defaults to 0.0.

  • y_rotation_axis_distance (float) – The distance from the axis of roataion on the y-axis in meters. Defaults to 0.0.

  • z_rotation_axis_distance (float) – The distance from the axis of rotation on the z-axis in meters. Defaults to 0.0.

  • x_rot_angle (float) – The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the x-axis. Defaults to 0.0.

  • y_rot_angle (float) – The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the x-axis. Defaults to 0.0.

  • z_rot_angle (float) – The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the z-axis. Defaults to 0.0.

name¶

The name of this force. It cannot be the same as any other force on an object.

Type

str

x¶

The newtons of force in the x direction (typically east/west). Can be positive or negative, with (+) being east and (-) being west.

Type

float

y¶

The newtons of force in the y direction (typically vertical). Can be positive or negative, with (+) being up and (-) being down.

Type

float

z¶

The newtons of force in the z direction (typically north/south). Can be positive or negative, with (+) being north and (-) being south.

Type

float

force_type¶
Represents the type of force this force is with the following values:

  • 0: Applied Force

  • 1: Gravitational Force

  • 2: Frictional Force (Not yet implemented)

  • 3: Tension (Not yet implemented)

  • 4: Air Resistance (Not yet implemented)

Note

Currently unused and not changed (will stay its initial value).

Type

int

x_rotation_axis_distance¶

The distance from the axis of rotation on the x-axis in meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

y_rotation_axis_distance¶

The distance from the axis of rotation on the y-axis in meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

z_rotation_axis_distance¶

The distance from the axis of rotation on the z-axis in meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

x_rot_angle¶

The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the x-axis.

Type

float

y_rot_angle¶

The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the y-axis.

Type

float

z_rot_angle¶

The angle, in radians, from the axis of rotation on the z-axis.

Type

float

x_torque¶

The amount of torque on the x axis in newton meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

y_torque¶

The amount of torque on the y axis in newton meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

z_torque¶

The amount of torque on the z axis in newton meters. Vector quantity.

Type

float

calculate_torque() → tuple¶

Calculate the torque this force applies on the x and y axis.

Torque for each axis can be calculated using the following equation:

torque = (distance from axis of rotation) * (force) * (sin(angle from axis of rotation))
Returns

The torque this force will apply to any object in the form (x_torque, y_torque, z_torque)

Return type

tuple( float, float)

module pysics.errors¶

exception pysics.errors.NameUsedError¶

Raised when user attempts to use a name for a new Force or PhysicsObject that has already been used by another thing of the same type.

exception pysics.errors.MassOfZeroError¶

Raised when the user attempts to use a mass of 0 for a PhysicsObject (prevents division by 0).

exception pysics.errors.MomentOfInertiaZeroError¶

Raised when the user attempts to use a moment of inertia of 0 for a PhysicsObject (prevents division by 0).
